articles.headline: China’s Exports Are Surging. Get Ready for the Global Backlash.
articles.snippet: Increasing overseas sales of manufactured goods are helping China’s economy and creating employment, but countries from Europe to South Asia may lose jobs.
articles.abstract: Increasing overseas sales of manufactured goods are helping China’s economy and creating employment, but countries from Europe to South Asia may lose jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s factory exports are powering ahead faster than almost anyone expected, putting jobs around the world in jeopardy and setting off a backlash that is gaining momentum.

articles.headline: Walmart Wants to Teach Store Managers Compassion
articles.snippet: The retailer brings about 2,000 managers a year to its headquarters to discuss how to relate to workers and customers, part of a U.S. corporate trend.
articles.abstract: The retailer brings about 2,000 managers a year to its headquarters to discuss how to relate to workers and customers, part of a U.S. corporate trend.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a stormy afternoon in Bentonville, Ark., a Walmart regional manager recounted a story about a moment when his humanity came up short.

articles.headline: Sprouts of Hope in a Gloomy Media Landscape
articles.snippet: A handful of digital start-ups are finding success — so far, at least — by learning lessons from their troubled predecessors.
articles.abstract: A handful of digital start-ups are finding success — so far, at least — by learning lessons from their troubled predecessors.
articles.lead_paragraph: This year is looking grim for the news business.
articles.byline: By Katie Robertson and Benjamin Mullin

articles.headline: ‘Jamming’: How Electronic Warfare Is Reshaping Ukraine’s Battlefields
articles.snippet: Drones have become a critical weapon for both sides, but a lack of coordination among troops has put Ukraine at a disadvantage.
articles.abstract: Drones have become a critical weapon for both sides, but a lack of coordination among troops has put Ukraine at a disadvantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian soldier swore and tore off his headset. His video monitor had gone blurry at first, the landscape of shattered trees and shell craters barely visible, before blacking out completely. The Russians had jammed the signal of his drone as it was flying outside the town of Kreminna in eastern Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Yurii Shyvala

articles.headline: On the Tripwire of a ‘Red Line,’ It’s Often Presidents Who Trip
articles.snippet: Barack Obama drew one for Syria. George W. Bush drew several, for North Korea and Iran. Now President Biden has drawn one for Israel. The hard part is figuring out what to do when they are crossed.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama drew one for Syria. George W. Bush drew several, for North Korea and Iran. Now President Biden has drawn one for Israel. The hard part is figuring out what to do when they are crossed.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Biden declared over the weekend that he was drawing a “red line” for Israel’s military action in Gaza, he appeared to be trying to raise the potential cost for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as their relationship plummets to new depths.

articles.headline: Special Counsel Who Investigated Biden Offers Fierce Defense of Report
articles.snippet: At a hearing, Republicans peppered Robert K. Hur about his justifications for not charging the president, and Democrats rebuked him for broad assertions about Mr. Biden’s memory.
articles.abstract: At a hearing, Republicans peppered Robert K. Hur about his justifications for not charging the president, and Democrats rebuked him for broad assertions about Mr. Biden’s memory.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert K. Hur, the special counsel who investigated President Biden, on Tuesday fiercely defended the disparaging assessment of the president’s mental state included in his final report — and his decision not to charge Mr. Biden with a crime.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Luke Broadwater

articles.headline: Inflation Ticked Up Last Month, Backing the Fed’s Caution on Rate Cuts
articles.snippet: Consumer prices climbed 3.2 percent last month from a year earlier, down notably from a 9.1 percent high in 2022, but still quicker than the roughly 2 percent that was normal before the pandemic.
articles.abstract: Consumer prices climbed 3.2 percent last month from a year earlier, down notably from a 9.1 percent high in 2022, but still quicker than the roughly 2 percent that was normal before the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inflation sped up slightly in February on an overall basis and a closely watched measure of underlying price increases was firmer than economists had expected.

articles.headline: Dating Apps Have Hit a Wall. Can They Turn Things Around?
articles.snippet: The apps have changed our love lives, but they haven’t been able to convince enough young users to pay.
articles.abstract: The apps have changed our love lives, but they haven’t been able to convince enough young users to pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: As online dating became as easy as swiping a finger across your phone screen, the companies who own apps like Tinder and Bumble became Wall Street darlings. But about a decade later, those platforms are now struggling to live up to expectations, and investors have grown frustrated and eager for something new.
